content.text: State the difference between a scalar quantity and a vector quantity
Define momentum <label>
During the test crash, the resultant force acting on the car is \(27 000 \mathrm{N}\). The car takes \(1.5 \mathrm{s}\) to come to rest. The deceleration is uniform
Calculate the initial velocity of the car
initial velocity =   .........
On Fig. 1.2, sketch a speed–time graph to show the motion of the car from time \(t = 0\) until the car becomes stationary

A test car crashes into a barrier to test the safety features. The test car has a total mass of \(950\mathrm{kg}\) . It is moving with constant velocity from time \(t = 0\) for 4.0 s. At \(t = 4.0\mathrm{s}\), the car hits the barrier
Fig. 1.1 shows the car as it hits the barrier
Describe an experiment to determine the spring constant of a spring
State:
• the apparatus you need
• details of how to take measurements
• how to calculate the spring constant
You may use the space below to draw a **labelled** diagram as part of your answer
Two springs Q and R are tested to determine their spring constants
Each spring is tested up to its limit of proportionality
Define 'limit of proportionality'
Table 2.1 shows the results of the tests
The total weight of the baby and the holder is 120 N
Calculate the extension of each spring for this weight
extension of spring Q =
extension of spring R =
The unstretched length of each spring is \(25 \text{cm}\)
State and explain which spring would be more suitable for the baby bouncer in Fig. 2.1
spring
explanation
Fig. 2.1 shows a baby in a baby bouncer. The baby bouncer consists of a holder suspended from a spring. The baby pushes his feet on the ground and bounces gently up and down
Explain why the shower bag is painted black
Explain a disadvantage of radiation from the Sun being the only source to heat the water
Solar energy is a renewable energy resource
State **two other** renewable energy resources
During the day, the Sun shines on the shower bag and some of the energy in the infrared radiation from the Sun transfers to the thermal energy stores of the water
The water absorbs \(60\%\) of the energy incident on the bag. The temperature of the water rises from \(10^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) to \(43^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)
The mass of the water in the bag is \(40\mathrm{kg}\). The specific heat capacity of water is \(4200\mathrm{J / (kg^{\circ}C)}\)
Calculate the energy incident on the shower bag during the day
Show your working
Fig. 3.1 shows a portable shower used on a campsite. The bag is filled with water. The water is heated using infrared radiation from the Sun

There is an electric field around sphere S

A small negatively charged particle is placed at position X
State the direction of the force on the negatively charged particle at X due to the electric field around sphere S
The negatively charged particle at X is released from rest
Describe the motion of the small negatively charged particle due to the electric field around sphere S
Explain why the paint particles spread out when they leave the nozzle
The sphere can be painted by hand using a paintbrush
Suggest and explain **one** advantage to using charged paint from a spray gun to paint sphere S
advantage
explanation
Fig. 5.3 shows sphere S being spray painted. Sphere S is negatively charged. As the paint particles exit the wide nozzle of the paint sprayer, they become charged with a positive charge
Fig. 5.1 shows a metal sphere S. The sphere has been charged with a negative charge
Describe **two** advantages of using Circuit B

A car windscreen is covered in condensation (small droplets of water). Thermal energy is used to remove the droplets of water. The thermal energy is provided by three resistors on the windscreen
Fig. 6.1 shows two possible circuits for the three resistors
The three resistors are identical

current =   .........

Initially the wooden barrier arm is horizontal

statement
explanation
The switch is opened. An operator decreases the potential difference across the coil and the switch is closed

statement

A student suggests that the soft iron bar A is replaced by a steel bar. Explain why a steel bar is less effective than a soft iron bar in the barrier

Fig. 7.2
Fig. 7.1 shows a barrier at the entrance to a car park. The wooden barrier arm has a weight of \(60 \text{N}\) which acts through the centre of gravity at the position shown on Fig. 7.1
Describe **one** difference between fission and fusion
A nucleus of boron (B) contains 5 protons and 5 neutrons. Complete the nuclide equation for this fission reaction
The isotope of boron is bombarded with neutrons then undergoes fission to form lithium and alpha-particles
The alpha-particles destroy the cancer cells. Suggest and explain **one** reason why alpha particles are more suitable than gamma radiation for use in this treatment of brain cancer
Other cancers are treated with gamma radiation. Describe **one** safety precaution a nurse or radiologist takes during this treatment
An isotope of boron is used in the treatment of cancer in the brain
Boron sticks to cancer cells in the brain
Fig. 9.1 shows a diagram of a transverse wave
From Fig. 9.1, identify all the lengths which represent **one** wavelength
Hydrogen in a very distant galaxy emits electromagnetic radiation which is observed on the Earth
Scientists on the Earth measure the wavelength of the radiation from the very distant galaxy. The wavelength is \(918 \text{nm}\)
On the Earth, hydrogen in the laboratory emits electromagnetic radiation of wavelength \(656 \text{nm}\)
Name the effect that the scientists observe and state what this shows about the very distant galaxy
Table 9.1 shows a wavelength of electromagnetic radiation from hydrogen observed in the laboratory and from three galaxies
The galaxies are at different distances from the Earth

table.html:
objectwavelength of hydrogen from object, observed on the Earth/nm
gas tube in laboratory656
nearby galaxy667
distant galaxy750
very distant galaxy918
